content: Peace Officer's Memorial Day (May 15th of every year by Act of Congress) Peace Officers Memorial Day is held annually in the United States on May 15 in honor of federal, state and local officers killed or disabled in the line of duty. Peace Officer's Memorial Day It is observed in conjunction with Police Week. ++++http://www.timeanddate.com/holidays/us/peace-officers-memorial-day ++++http://www.aphf.org/memday.html RIP to those who gave all. Many thanks for your service, and to all those who served and are serving. Salute
reply: Peace Officer's Memorial Day (May 15th of every year by Act of Congress) Peace Officers Memorial Day is held annually in the United States on May 15 in honor of federal, state and local officers killed or disabled in the line of duty. Many thanks for your service, and to all those who served and are serving. Salute
title: Peace Officer's Memorial Day

content: Thought I would mention a few friends I have lost along the way. Joe Martyna, Florida Fish & Wildlife Commission, previously Florida Marine Patrol. Joe was a pilot and flew a Jet Ranger helicopter. Joe past away last year from a heart attack. I knew Joe not only from working law enforcement missions but we played together on a charity football team to raise money for the athletic programs of the high schools in the FL Keys. The last time I saw him was on TV. He was flying a FWC Jet Ranger in an episode of "CSI Miami". Bob Beckett, Monroe County Sheriff's Detective (FL Keys). Bob worked with us countless nights on the US Customs boats and a number of seizures on land. Bob volunteered to work in Bosnia. One morning, he did not show up for a meeting. When they went to check on him, he had died of a heart attack in the shower. I believe he was 39 at the time. Mark Anna'belle, Mark was a Marine Enforcement Officer assigned to the Key Largo Marine Unit. I worked with him a number of years. Unfortunately, Mark got hooked on Oxyconton and eventually overdosed. I hate that I never got to know this Monroe County Deputy enough to be able to remember his name. He had been a LT with Dade County Sheriff's Office (Miami) but transferred to the Monroe County S.O. as a Deputy. All the guys said he never EVER pulled any attitude about starting over at the bottom. This Deputy pulled out in front of an 18 wheeler one evening in Key Largo. He died instantly leaving behind a wife, a young son and young daughter. There must have been 150+ LEO's from every agency in South Florida that attended his funeral. And finally, the Supervisory Agent that was in Marathon, FL. Sadly, another who I didn't get to know well enough to remember his name. He was facing some pretty risky surgery and was told he may not survive. The poor guy was in severe pain all the time. He took his life with a shotgun. Remember all the LEO's who have lost their lives. We had an Officer close by in Manchester, NH. He had saved some homeless guy's life a few years back. Then last year, that same homeless guy fatally shot the officer. The local news told of how this officer dedicated himself to the safety of the homeless. Don

content: "http://www.odmp.org/officer/15024-first-sergeant-frankie-lee-lingard" {First Sergeant Frankie Lee Lingard South Carolina Highway Patrol South Carolina End of Watch: Wednesday, December 31, 1997 Biographical Info Age: 39 Tour of Duty: 15 years Badge Number: Not available Incident Details Cause of Death: Gunfire Date of Incident: Wednesday, December 31, 1997 Weapon Used: Handgun Suspect Info: Sentenced to death} Brandon's Uncle. My Grandson's best friend and neighbor, Brandon. This was his Uncle. Thank You. RIP Frankie! God Bless you and your family. (My Son-in-law is Sgt Sowards Lexington County, SC) Google "Barry Sowards" if you wish. Frankie Lingard was a wonderful person. Wish you could have known him. (his PHOTO is on the link above)

content: "http://www.odmp.org/officer/10957-trooper-george-tillman-radford" Please read this: George Tillman Radford South Carolina Highway Patrol South Carolina End of Watch: Saturday, October 29, 1988 Biographical Info Age: 42 Tour of Duty: Not available Badge Number: Not available Incident Details Cause of Death: Gunfire Date of Incident: Saturday, October 29, 1988 Weapon Used: Gun; Unknown type Suspect Info: Acquitted after five trials Trooper Radford was shot and killed while on duty. The suspect had submerged his body in a pond off of SC Highway 34, where it was found the following day. The suspect in his murder was found not-guilty in his fifth trial. The juries in the previous four trials all found him guilty. Trooper Radford was survived by his wife, daughter, mother, and three siblings. SUSPECT INFO: AQUITTED after FIVE TRIALS A special prayer for Trooper Radford. "no justice" SUSPECT ACQUITTED
reply: "http://www.odmp.org/officer/10957-trooper-george-tillman-radford" Please read this: George Tillman Radford South Carolina Highway Patrol South Carolina End of Watch: Saturday, October 29, 1988 Biographical Info Age: 42 Tour of Duty: Not available Badge Number: Not available Incident Details Cause of Death: Gunfire Date of Incident: Saturday, October 29, 1988 Weapon Used: Gun; Unknown type Suspect Info: Acquitted after five trials Trooper Radford was shot and killed while on duty. title: Peace Officer's Memorial Day

content: "http://www.midlandsconnect.com/news/video.aspx?id=296691" This is a local video. From WACH TV. A "Remembering The Officers Killed in The Line of Duty" The video is only 1 Minute and 59 Seconds but is VERY Heart-wrenching. (Found this while looking for a slain County Sheriff Deputy that was shot in the head and is now shown at the Police Academy as a film of basically WHAT NOT TO DO which means HOW TO STAY ALIVE as a Police Officer) His widow is very sad that her husband's death is viewed as a preventive measure but understands the need. He was shot in the head. His mistake??? Walked to a "traffic stop" in SC but did not keep up his GUARD. Police now approach traffic stops very cautiously. Not so then. His name was Mark. Thank you.
reply: "http://www.midlandsconnect.com/news/video.aspx?id=296691" This is a local video. From WACH TV. content: "http://www.odmp.org/historical.php" This is "RECENTLY DISCOVERED" Begins in the Year 1877 in TX! Most all are by GUNFIRE! In other words..Killed in The Line Of Duty! Some were "PROHIBITION OFFICER" So far all of those are in WV! One in 1908 with Cause Of Death "Struck by Streetcar" But all of these are before 1940 with the exception of two.

content: DAD! I understand!! I did look up TN for you! There is a "historian" here .. can't remember the name. But the one link above shows records from 1877. Some States list some from the 1700's. I never knew records were kept from those years. I live near the SC Police Academy and the LE Hall Of Fame. TN has one too, I think. See ya at Jarhead or Renee's. Can't help it...I really like you Dad!

content: quote: Originally posted by Agent991: "http://www.midlandsconnect.com/news/video.aspx?id=296691" This is a local video. From WACH TV. A "Remembering The Officers Killed in The Line of Duty" The video is only 1 Minute and 59 Seconds but is VERY Heart-wrenching. (Found this while looking for a slain County Sheriff Deputy that was shot in the head and is now shown at the Police Academy as a film of basically WHAT NOT TO DO which means HOW TO STAY ALIVE as a Police Officer) His widow is very sad that her husband's death is viewed as a preventive measure but understands the need. He was shot in the head. His mistake??? Walked to a "traffic stop" in SC but did not keep up his GUARD. Police now approach traffic stops very cautiously. Not so then. His name was Mark. Thank you. Agent, I watched the video. Very moving. Thank you for posting that. I once again reiterate my earlier sentiments to all LEO's out there (and, yes, this includes my ex-wife, a Maricopa County Sheriff Deputy - I hate what you did to me, Camy, but watch your six and know that we all support you): Y'all do a seemingly thankless job. But it is only seemingly. Know that everyday you put that uniform on, prayers are going up for you. Remember that you serve us, just as all veterans once served you. Dignity, kindness, understanding and respect are the tools of your trade. But never turn your back on them for a second. Watch your six, stay safe, and go home knowing that you protected your community. It isn't the Thin Blue Line. It is 1* My respect, admiration and appreciation. It's not that there is no God or that He isn't listening. You're probably just asking the wrong questions.
